Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Recognising the effects of words, signing, gestures and body language on the way communications are received by others
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •understanding how gestures may have different meanings in different cultural contexts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Understanding that symbols, gestures and body language are key components of communication in first nations australian communities

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Viewing short films and discussing how characters use words and body language to convey emotions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how language, facial expressions and gestures are used to interact with others when asking for and providing information, making offers, exclaiming, requesting and giving commands
Elaboration: Learning the difference between closed questions; for example, "are you ready?" and open questions; for example, "what made this text so exciting?"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language to provide reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
Elaboration: Using words including "because" to introduce reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •practising how to turn simple statements into questions; for example, “I like noodles.”  ‘Do you like noodles?”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language to provide reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
Elaboration: Using words including "because" to introduce reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
EALDElaboration: •learning language to express negative responses, for example ‘I don’t like noodles.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore language to provide reasons for likes, dislikes and preferences
Elaboration: Exploring comparative words (adjectives) to express the degree of preference; for example, "better", "faster"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how texts are organised according to their purpose, such as to recount, narrate, express opinion, inform, report and explain
Elaboration: Discussing and comparing the purposes and organisation of familiar texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how texts are organised according to their purpose, such as to recount, narrate, express opinion, inform, report and explain
Elaboration: Becoming familiar with the typical stages of types of texts; for example, recount and procedure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how texts are organised according to their purpose, such as to recount, narrate, express opinion, inform, report and explain
Elaboration: Recognising that the structure of a text may include words and pictures; for example, an informative text may include words, illustrations and diagrams

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how repetition, rhyme and rhythm create cohesion in simple poems, chants and songs
Elaboration: Identifying patterns of repetition in texts; for example, repetition of sentence patterns such as "have you seen ..."

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Explore how repetition, rhyme and rhythm create cohesion in simple poems, chants and songs
Elaboration: Discussing different poems and identifying rhyme; for example, end of line rhyme

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how print and screen texts are organised using features such as page numbers, tables of content, headings and titles, navigation buttons, swipe screens, verbal commands, links and images
Elaboration: Comparing the layout of print and digital texts; for example, the layout of print and images in an information book and the layout of information in an online text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a simple sentence consists of a single independent clause representing a single event or idea
Elaboration: Knowing that a single event or idea can include a process a happening or a state (verb), the participant or who or what is involved (noun group/phrase), and the surrounding circumstances (adverb group/phrase); for example, "teddy (participant: who or what is involved) read (process: a happening) the book (participant: who or what is involved) in the library (circumstance: where he read)."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to differentiate simple sentences from sentence fragments; for example “Is this a sentence? “In the playground”,  Is this a sentence? “Ali is playing in the playground.” “

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a simple sentence consists of a single independent clause representing a single event or idea
Elaboration: Knowing that a single event or idea can include a process a happening or a state (verb), the participant or who or what is involved (noun group/phrase), and the surrounding circumstances (adverb group/phrase); for example, "teddy (participant: who or what is involved) read (process: a happening) the book (participant: who or what is involved) in the library (circumstance: where he read)."
EALDElaboration: •using colour coding or visuals to demonstrate subject and verb to create a sentence, then building in the object and further information using questions as prompts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a simple sentence consists of a single independent clause representing a single event or idea
Elaboration: Understanding that simple sentences answer questions such as "what is happening?" and "who or what is involved?" along with details such as "where?", "when?", "how?"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that words can represent people, places and things (nouns, including pronouns), happenings and states (verbs), qualities (adjectives) and details such as when, where and how (adverbs)
Elaboration: Understanding that words or groups of words can represent the participants (nouns; for example, people, places, things) that are involved in various activities or processes (verbs of doing, saying, thinking, being), and the details or circumstances surrounding the activity (adjectives and adverbs that answer "when?", "where?", "how?")
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •deconstructing and reconstructing sentences into ‘chunks’, not just individual words; for example adjectives and nouns grouped together

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that words can represent people, places and things (nouns, including pronouns), happenings and states (verbs), qualities (adjectives) and details such as when, where and how (adverbs)
Elaboration: Understanding that words or groups of words can represent the participants (nouns; for example, people, places, things) that are involved in various activities or processes (verbs of doing, saying, thinking, being), and the details or circumstances surrounding the activity (adjectives and adverbs that answer "when?", "where?", "how?")
EALDElaboration: •using colour-coding to demonstrate parts of sentences and types of words

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that words can represent people, places and things (nouns, including pronouns), happenings and states (verbs), qualities (adjectives) and details such as when, where and how (adverbs)
Elaboration: Recognising how a sentence can be made more specific by adding adjectives, adverbs and precise verbs

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Comparing images from texts where images of the same subject are represented differently; for example, a cartoon image of an animal, a photograph of an animal and a digital image of an animal in an advertisement

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Understanding how authors and illustrators build up meaning across a sequence of images

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Understanding that some images convey meaning that is not included in the accompanying written text; for example, a diagram shows information about how parts of a plant are connected, which is not explained in the print text

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Compare how images in different types of texts contribute to meaning
Elaboration: Exploring images in stories and cultural accounts by first nations australian authors and discussing the impact this may have

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise the vocabulary of learning area topics
Elaboration: Using appropriate topic-specific vocabulary when discussing a learning area topic
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using images or concrete objects or bilingual word lists to build and practise vocabulary

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise the vocabulary of learning area topics
Elaboration: Using appropriate topic-specific vocabulary when discussing a learning area topic
EALDElaboration: •using visuals and real-life experiences to learn new vocabulary

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise the vocabulary of learning area topics
Elaboration: Using appropriate vocabulary for an acknowledgement of country at assemblies and other school events, using protocols to recognise the traditional owners of country or place

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Recognise the vocabulary of learning area topics
Elaboration: Identifying words for topics studied at school; for example, vocabulary used for weather and seasons

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for familiar proper nouns
Elaboration: Using intonation and pauses in response to punctuation when reading

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for familiar proper nouns
Elaboration: Identifying different sentence boundary punctuation when reading

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for familiar proper nouns
Elaboration: Writing different types of sentences; for example, statements and questions, and discussing appropriate punctuation

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that written language uses punctuation such as full stops, question marks and exclamation marks, and uses capital letters for familiar proper nouns
Elaboration: Identifying and using capital letters to name places and holidays

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing how animal characters reflect human characteristics; for example, the creation of animal characters and their human qualities in fables by wide-ranging world authors
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of texts which reflect their own culture and language or are written or illustrated by Australians who share their cultural and linguistic background

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing how animal characters reflect human characteristics; for example, the creation of animal characters and their human qualities in fables by wide-ranging world authors
EALDElaboration: •mixing and matching character or setting pictures to written descriptions using learnt vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing how characters, settings and events are described or depicted in literature by first nations australian authors and illustrators

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how language and images are used to create characters, settings and events in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing the events associated with australian animal characters and what is learnt about their characters in picture books from wide-ranging australian authors

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss literary texts and share responses by making connections with students' own experiences
Elaboration: Generating questions about characters, settings and events from books and sharing responses

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss literary texts and share responses by making connections with students' own experiences
Elaboration: Discussing different texts and offering opinions about how they reflect their own experiences

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss literary texts and share responses by making connections with students' own experiences
Elaboration: Expressing responses to characters and events in stories using drawing and role-play

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss literary texts and share responses by making connections with students' own experiences
Elaboration: Identifying who is telling the story in different texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plot, character and setting, which are features of stories
Elaboration: Recognising similar characters and settings in different types of literary texts; for example, traditional tales, narrative poems and fables
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •hearing models of language, through role play and authentic experiences for commenting on texts; for example cause and effect sentences such as “The dogs were scared because the cat hissed at them.”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plot, character and setting, which are features of stories
Elaboration: Recognising similar characters and settings in different types of literary texts; for example, traditional tales, narrative poems and fables
EALDElaboration: •hearing models of sentence patterns that they can adapt by inserting the appropriate words and phrases; for example  There are _____ (three)  characters in this story. A ___________,  (a lazy cat )a___________(smart dog) and a ___________. (girl called Izzy).”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plot, character and setting, which are features of stories
Elaboration: Discussing whether features of settings, including time (year, season) and place (country or city), are realistic or imagined

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss plot, character and setting, which are features of stories
Elaboration: Discussing how plots develop, including beginnings (orientation), how the problem (complication) is introduced and solved (resolution)

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to and discuss poems, chants, rhymes and songs, and imitate and invent sound patterns, including alliteration and rhyme
Elaboration: Listening to performance poetry, chants or songs from first nations australians

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to and discuss poems, chants, rhymes and songs, and imitate and invent sound patterns, including alliteration and rhyme
Elaboration: Exploring poetry, chants and songs from asian cultures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Listen to and discuss poems, chants, rhymes and songs, and imitate and invent sound patterns, including alliteration and rhyme
Elaboration: Listening to haiku poems about familiar topics such as nature and the seasons

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally retell or adapt a familiar story using plot and characters, language features, including vocabulary and structure of a familiar text, through role-play, writing, drawing or digital tools
Elaboration: Writing character descriptions
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •sequencing sentence cards to retell a story

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally retell or adapt a familiar story using plot and characters, language features, including vocabulary and structure of a familiar text, through role-play, writing, drawing or digital tools
Elaboration: Writing character descriptions
EALDElaboration: •identifying verbs and simple temporal connectives

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally retell or adapt a familiar story using plot and characters, language features, including vocabulary and structure of a familiar text, through role-play, writing, drawing or digital tools
Elaboration: Imitating a characteristic piece of speech or dialogue, or the attitudes or expressions of favourite characters in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally retell or adapt a familiar story using plot and characters, language features, including vocabulary and structure of a familiar text, through role-play, writing, drawing or digital tools
Elaboration: Retelling key events in stories using oral language, visual arts, digital tools or performance

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss different texts and identify some features that indicate their purposes
Elaboration: Discussing a range of texts encountered in school and in the community and identifying their purpose
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using images and visual cues to identify text purpose; for example diagrams are likely to indicate an informative text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss different texts and identify some features that indicate their purposes
Elaboration: Recognising that types of texts with similar purposes usually have predictable structures

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills, including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours, and responding to the contributions of others and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Using turn-taking in group and pair work
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •interacting in pairs or smaller groups use role play; cue cards or Readers Theatre and encourage the use of both home languages or dialects as well as English to develop confidence

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills, including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours, and responding to the contributions of others and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Building a conversation by staying on topic, supporting other speakers, eliciting responses, listening supportively and attentively, asking relevant questions, providing useful feedback and prompting

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills, including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours, and responding to the contributions of others and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Participating in informal and structured class, group and pair discussions about content area topics, ideas and information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills, including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours, and responding to the contributions of others and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Interacting appropriately with peers, teachers and visitors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills, including turn-taking, speaking clearly, using active listening behaviours, and responding to the contributions of others and contributing ideas and questions
Elaboration: Formulating different types of questions to ask a speaker such as open and closed questions, and "when", "why" and "how" questions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe some similarities and differences between imaginative, informative and persuasive texts
Elaboration: Comparing and discussing texts, identifying some features that distinguish those that "tell stories" from those that "give opinions"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe some similarities and differences between imaginative, informative and persuasive texts
Elaboration: Selecting texts for a particular purpose or task; for example, a website that will give information about a learning area topic, a book that will tell a story about an animal

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts using developing phonic knowledge, phrasing and fluency, and monitoring meaning using context and grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Recognising most high-frequency words when reading a text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read decodable and authentic texts using developing phonic knowledge, phrasing and fluency, and monitoring meaning using context and grammatical knowledge
Elaboration: Self-correcting or asking for assistance when meaning breaks down

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning when listening, viewing and reading to build literal and inferred meaning by drawing on vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures
Elaboration: Identifying information and details from spoken informative texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •explanations of any unfamiliar cultural references in a text; for example swimming lessons

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning when listening, viewing and reading to build literal and inferred meaning by drawing on vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures
Elaboration: Building topic knowledge and learning new vocabulary before and during reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning when listening, viewing and reading to build literal and inferred meaning by drawing on vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures
Elaboration: Making predictions from the cover, from illustrations and at points in the text before reading on, and confirming and adjusting understanding after reading

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning when listening, viewing and reading to build literal and inferred meaning by drawing on vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures
Elaboration: Drawing inferences and explaining inferences using clues from the text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies such as visualising, predicting, connecting, summarising and questioning when listening, viewing and reading to build literal and inferred meaning by drawing on vocabulary and growing knowledge of context and text structures
Elaboration: Making connections with existing knowledge and personal experiences

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Applying emerging knowledge of text structure and grammar when creating text
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •additional support with the grammatical structures needed for different types of writing; for example using past tense in recounts.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Applying emerging knowledge of text structure and grammar when creating text
EALDElaboration: •modelling of the drafting and editing process

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Using learning area vocabulary when creating text

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Creating digital images and composing a story or information sequence on screen using images and captions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Adding or deleting words on a page or screen to improve meaning; for example, adding an adjective to add meaning to a noun

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Beginning to use dictionaries and resources to check and correct spelling

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and re-read to edit short written and/or multimodal texts to report on a topic, express an opinion or recount a real or imagined event, using grammatically correct simple sentences, some topic-specific vocabulary, sentence boundary punctuation and correct spelling of some one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Identifying words that might not be spelt correctly

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations on personal and learnt topics, which include an opening, middle and concluding statement, some topic-specific vocabulary and appropriate gesture, volume and pace
Elaboration: Reporting the results of group activities
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to hear other students, who are proficient in SAE give presentations, so they have a model of appropriate volume, pace, gesture.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations on personal and learnt topics, which include an opening, middle and concluding statement, some topic-specific vocabulary and appropriate gesture, volume and pace
Elaboration: Reporting the results of group activities
EALDElaboration: •practising and presenting to a partner

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations on personal and learnt topics, which include an opening, middle and concluding statement, some topic-specific vocabulary and appropriate gesture, volume and pace
Elaboration: Explaining how to do or make something

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations on personal and learnt topics, which include an opening, middle and concluding statement, some topic-specific vocabulary and appropriate gesture, volume and pace
Elaboration: Giving short oral presentations about areas of interest or content area topics, speaking clearly and with appropriate volume, and using content-specific vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations on personal and learnt topics, which include an opening, middle and concluding statement, some topic-specific vocabulary and appropriate gesture, volume and pace
Elaboration: Experimenting with volume and pace for particular purposes; for example, presenting information, retelling stories and reciting rhymes and poems

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations on personal and learnt topics, which include an opening, middle and concluding statement, some topic-specific vocabulary and appropriate gesture, volume and pace
Elaboration: Giving reasons why the class should learn a particular game

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words using unjoined lower-case and upper-case letters
Elaboration: Continuing to develop a functional pencil grip/grasp

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Segment words into separate phonemes (sounds), including consonant blends or clusters at the beginnings and ends of words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Saying sounds in order for a given spoken word; for example, "s-p-oo-n" and "f-i-s-t"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to repeat the teacher’s examples of segmented words and practise different combinations of sounds which can be achieved by reading rhythmic, rhyming texts like picture books or poems and singing and reciting poems and rhymes with the word on display

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Segment words into separate phonemes (sounds), including consonant blends or clusters at the beginnings and ends of words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Saying sounds in order for a given spoken word; for example, "s-p-oo-n" and "f-i-s-t"
EALDElaboration: •practising different combinations of sounds

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally manipulate phonemes in spoken words by addition, deletion and substitution of initial, medial and final phonemes to generate new words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Adding, substituting or deleting phonemes in any position in one-syllable words with up to 4 phonemes
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models of how sounds are pronounced in English, including showing lip and tongue positions

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally manipulate phonemes in spoken words by addition, deletion and substitution of initial, medial and final phonemes to generate new words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Substituting medial sounds in spoken words to make new words; for example, "pin", "pen", "pan"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Orally manipulate phonemes in spoken words by addition, deletion and substitution of initial, medial and final phonemes to generate new words (phonological awareness)
Elaboration: Substituting final sounds in spoken words; for example, substitute the "t" in "pet" with "g" to form a new word "peg"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short vowels, common long vowels, consonant blends and digraphs to write words and blend these to read one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Using knowledge of letters and sounds to write words with short vowels; for example, "man" and common long vowel sounds; for example, "time"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use short vowels, common long vowels, consonant blends and digraphs to write words and blend these to read one- and two-syllable words
Elaboration: Using knowledge of letter sounds to write single-syllable words with consonant digraphs and consonant blends; for example, "wish" and "rest"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that a letter can represent more than one sound and that a syllable must contain a vowel sound
Elaboration: Recognising that letters can have more than one sound; for example, the letter "u" in "cut", "put", "use" and the letter "a" in "cat", "father", "any"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using a colour coding or highlighting system to identify where the same sound is created using different letters; for example “bee”, “tea”

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that a letter can represent more than one sound and that a syllable must contain a vowel sound
Elaboration: Recognising sounds that can be produced by different letters; for example, the "s" sound in "sat" and "cent"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Spell one- and two-syllable words with common letter patterns
Elaboration: Writing one- and two-syllable words containing known blends; for example, "bl" and "st"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •building word banks  and co-constructing anchor charts to show a phoneme (sound), along with its different grapheme (letter) matches, with attention to the meaning and use of known words, for example  bed, head

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read and write an increasing number of high-frequency words
Elaboration: Learning an increasing number of high-frequency words and reading them independently; for example, "one", "have" and "pretty"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and know how to use grammatical morphemes to create word families
Elaboration: Building word families from common morphemes; for example, "play", "plays", "playing", "played", "playground"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and know how to use grammatical morphemes to create word families
Elaboration: Using morphemes to read words; for example, by recognising the base word in words such as "walk-ed"
